DOC.HEAD: California Eyes Curb on Sale of `Junk Bonds'
DOC.TEXT: State regulators, spurred by the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan, intend to prohibit the sale of high-risk junk bonds from the offices of California's state-chartered thrifts. A temporary order will be issued next week by the state Savings and Loan Department, Chief Deputy Commissioner William Davis said. He said his agency will then begin procedures to make the order permanent. The order will affect about 117 state-chartered S&L offices. Currently, no junk bond sales are taking place in any California thrift offices, although such practices have occurred in the past, Davis said. ``Just so no one gets that idea in mind, we are saying you can't do it,'' Davis said Tuesday. ``We just don't think it is a good idea.'' An estimated 23,000 investors _ mostly retirees in Southern California _ claim they lost nearly $250 million when they purchased uninsured corporate bonds sold by American Continental Corp., primarily through the 26 offices of Lincoln Savings, its wholly owned subsidiary. The Irvine-based thrift was seized in April by federal regulators. The takeover is expected to cost $2.5 billion, the nation's largest thrift bailout. Many investors said that because the bonds were sold at savings and loan offices, they assumed they were insured against loss. The bonds, sold in 1987 and 1988, now are considered virtually worthless. Davis said similar rules on the sale of junk bonds are apparently being drafted by the U.S. Office of Thrift Supervision and by the U.S. Savings and Loan League, a trade association for the industry. John Jones, a spokesman in Washington for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said Wednesday he didn't know of any such orders. The chairman of the federal Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard Breeden, suggested earlier this year that Congress consider a ban on junk bond sales from S&L offices. New regulations passed by Congress already require S&Ls to get rid of their own junk-bond investments by 1994; those rules don't apply to companies that are using S&L offices to sell junk bonds to the public. At Lincoln, the actual approval to sell the bonds was given by the state Department of Corporations, which is under fire for its role. With that approval, the state Savings and Loan Department gave Lincoln Savings permission to lease space in each of its offices for employees of American Continental to sell the bonds. ``There was nothing illegal or illicit about what they were doing,'' Davis said. But many of the senior citizens were not knowledgeable enough to realize the risk they were taking, he added.
